moves.1. c4: I like to play this opening
moves.1... c5: he must like the off-center games too
moves.3. Nf3: trying to prepare to eventually get my pawn to d4
moves.4. g3: I'll castle after I move the bishop to g2
moves.4... e6: he wants to get to d5 before I get to d4?
moves.5. d3: I protect the c-pawn, expecting d5
moves.6. Bg2: I want to get castled... the pawn trades can wait
moves.6... g6: he wants the other diagonal for his bishop
moves.8. Bg5: I pin the knight, expecting him to castle anyway
moves.8... Qd7: the pin must have made him nervous
moves.9. a3: I decide on a queen-side pawn attack
moves.10... Nxe4: he wants to trade (didn't think he would)
moves.11. dxe4: now my pawns are double on the e-file and I've blocked my long diagonal
moves.12. Qd2: I decide to remove the dark-squared bishops (when people do this to my king's bishop in this castling position, they usually end up with a good attack)
moves.12... f6: he tries to run off the bishop (and creates an escape hole for the king)
moves.13. Bh6: I think I'm forcing the bishop trade
moves.14. Nh4: I try to lure the pawn up another square
moves.14... Qf7: he fortifies and attacks my "naked" c-pawn
moves.15. Bxg7: I force the bishop trade anyway
moves.15... Kxg7: I expected him to take it with the queen
moves.16. f4: I ignore the c-pawn weakness and attack the king-side pawns
moves.16... b6: I guess he wants to put the bishop on the a-h diagonal
moves.18. Qd3: I offer a queen trade to undouble my pawns
moves.18... Qf7: he declines to help me out
moves.19... dxe3: he sort of had to trade
moves.20. Qxe3: he could gain another pawn here if he plays cxb, axb, Nxb
moves.20... exf4: he trades on the other side
moves.21. Rxf4: bad move by me... now g5 could cost me a piece
moves.21... Kh8: did he see something I didn't?
moves.22. bxc5: I keep from losing a pawn on this side, but I'm still risking a piece on the other flank
moves.23. Qxc5: I come out a pawn upo and hope the attack on his knight will keep him distracted
moves.23... Ne5: It works!.. now to get those pieces out of there!
moves.24. Raf1: doubling rooks on his queen (hiding behind a pawn) should keep him from playing g5
moves.24... Qg7: he moves the queen out of fire
moves.25... Bd7: this move links his rooks and protects all his pieces
moves.26. Qd6: I keep the pressure on the pawn
moves.28. Qb6: he has ignored g5 for so long, I think I even forgot about it!
moves.28... Nc4: he forks my queen and pawn (both unprotected)
moves.30... Nc2: he's after a queen-rook fork on d4
moves.31. Qb6: luckily, I notice it and move the queen
moves.31... Rab8: he goes after the queen again
moves.32. Qc5: I move the queen and try to limit the knight's activities at the same time
moves.33. Qd6: I still need to protect again Nd4 (Nd4 followed by Ne2 would fork the King and rook)
moves.34. Qc5: I keep the queen near d4, but with the rook as backup, I can't stop the knight
moves.34... Nd4: he sees it alright (apparently, he still hasn't seen g5)
moves.35. Rb2: I move the attacked rook and protect e2
moves.35... Ne2+: he goes there anyway (his bishop has his back!)
moves.36. Rxe2: I lose a rook for a knight, but at least he won't fork me again
moves.37. Rf2: I finally get one of my pieces out of the pawn fork threat
moves.37... Bb5: he puts the bishop back on the pawn
moves.38. Bf1: I don't know why I did that!
moves.38... Rd1: just what I would have done!
moves.39. Kg2: I get the king out so at least it will be a fair trade
moves.39... Rc8: ??? surely he meant to go to d8, but I'm thankful for the gift
moves.40. Qxc8+: I take it and check is a bonus!
moves.40... Qg8: he blocks with the queen (his only move really)
moves.41. Qc5: I considered trading queens and picking off the f-pawn, but the passed a-pawn scared me
moves.41... Bxf1+: he's ready to trade the other pieces too
moves.42. Rxf1: I really don't have a choice
moves.42... Rxf1: we trade bishops and now he wants to trade rooks too
moves.43... Qe8: he picks on my isolated pawn
moves.44. Qc3: I attack his weak pawn (I think I should have played Qc4, protecting mine and attacking his a-pawn)
moves.44... Qb5+: he checks me instead of taking the pawn!
moves.45. Ke1: I need to get my king over to the a-file
moves.45... Qb1+: he checks me again, forking the pawn in the process
moves.46. Kd2: I keep going toward the a-file
moves.46... Qa2+: he still prefers checks to taking the pawn!
moves.47. Qc2: I'm close enough to the a-file to offer to trade queens now
moves.49. Qc2 Qa5+ 50. Kc1 Qe1+ 51. Kb2 Qb4+ 5: he's trying to get a perpetual check stalemate, so I work on a plan to hide behind the isolated pawn
moves.56. Kd4 Qb4+ 57. Ke3 Qb6+ 58. Ke2 Qb5+ 5: finally I move where he cannot put me in check
moves.62... Qe6: he wants the pawn now so he can continue checking me
moves.63. Qd5: I protect it and attack the queen
moves.63... Qe7: he backs up but stays close
moves.64. Qa8+: I check him and attack the a-pawn
moves.65. Nf3: I can't take his pawn without giving up mine
moves.66. Qd5: I offer to trade queens again
moves.67. e5: if he doesn't take it, I'll play Qd6 followed by e6, etc.
moves.68. Qxe5+: now he's forced to trade queens!
moves.69. Nxe5: now I just need to get my knight to the a-file!
moves.69... Kf6: he's headed there too, no doubt!
moves.70. Nc4: my knight may be a "short range" weapon, but it moves faster than a king
moves.71. Kf3: I bring my king over too
moves.72... a5: probably a mistake.. he should have tried to block my king with Kd4
moves.73. Kf4: I decide the knight can handle it and head for the other two pawns
moves.73... h6: he prevents my king from coming closer to them
moves.75. g5: this is probably a bad move by me... I think h4 would have been better
moves.75... h5: he wants to keep the pawns
moves.76... Kd5: he heads back for the a-file
moves.77. Na4: I make sure his only move will be the King
moves.77... Ke6: he changes directions again (and that is a big mistake, Kd6 or Kd4 are better)
moves.78. Ke4: now his King gave me an opening
moves.79. Nc3: my king is close enough to stop the a-pawn, so I'll send the knight to the other flank
moves.80. Nb5: this will force the king back to the 7th rank
moves.81. Nc7+: I want the king to move away from the pawns before my kig goes after the a-pawn
moves.82. Nd5: I go to the king for protection
moves.82... a3: he makes a run for it
moves.83... Ke6: I think he's willing to give up the a-pawn to save the others
moves.85. Nb5+: he falls into a knight fork. The a-pawn is lost and, without the a-pawn to distract the knight, he resigns
